Subject: Philosophy
Content: Write your responses in English.

Subject: Philosophy
Content:
You want if possible - and there is no madder 'if possible' - to abolish suffering; and we? - it
really does seem that we would rather increase it and make it worse than it has ever been! Wellbeing
as you understand it - that is no goal, that seems to us an end! A state which soon renders man
ludicrous and contemptible - which makes it desirable that he should perish! The discipline of
suffering, of great suffering - do you not know that it is this discipline alone which has created every
elevation of mankind hitherto? That tension of the soul in misfortune which cultivates its strength,
its terror at the sight of great destruction, its inventiveness and bravery in undergoing, enduring,
interpreting, exploiting misfortune, and whatever of depth, mystery, mask, spirit, cunning and
greatness has been bestowed upon it - has it not been bestowed through suffering, through the
discipline of great suffering?
Source: F Nietzsche, Beyond Good and Evil, Penguin Group, London, 2003, p. 155

Subject: Philosophy
Content:
With reference to the passage above, explain how Nietzsche might respond to the view that
self-discipline is a key ingredient in the good life.

Subject: Philosophy
Content:
How might one other thinker studied in Unit 3 respond to Nietzsche's view on the role of
self-discipline in the good life?

Subject: Philosophy
Content:
What is the role of suffering in the good life? Provide your own justified response to this question.
Support your reasoning with an example.

Subject: Philosophy
Content:
Distributive justice, the first type, organizes the allotment of public goods-honor, money, property.
It depends on a "geometric" or proportional notion of equality. For instance, two people get an equal
amount to eat for dinner when each is served a portion in proportion to his appetite. Although one
diner may get a larger serving than another, each will have been treated equally provided that in
each case the serving matches the appetite. Every type of regime has its own principle of desert for
deciding how to make proportional distributions: aristocracies, for instance, assign greater benefits
to nobly born citizens. Aristotle advocates instead an approach in which people receive benefits
from the public store equivalent to what they have given to it, and he consistently argues, for
instance, that the rich should contribute proportionally more wealth to the public store and receive
proportionally more honor in return. Honor is the good that the poor have to give.
Source: DS Allen, Talking to Strangers: Anxieties of Citizenship Since Brown v. Board of Education,
The University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 2006, pp. 121 and 122

Subject: Philosophy
Content:
Consider the following viewpoint: 'Justice involves distributing society's goods unevenly.'
How would Allen draw on Aristotle's approach described in the passage above, to respond
to this viewpoint? Use a contemporary example of your own to support your response.

Subject: Philosophy
Content:
How might one other thinker studied in Unit 3 respond to the view that uneven distribution of
goods is just?

Subject: Philosophy
Content:
To what extent does the good life with others require that everyone has an equal share? Provide
your own justified response to this question.

Subject: Philosophy
Content:
The following extract is from an interview with Violet CoCo by The Philosophy Club. CoCo is an
environmental activist and a member of Extinction Rebellion, a global movement that agitates for
government action on climate change. The group organises acts of nonviolent civil disobedience
a form of protest where laws or the instructions of authorities are deliberately disobeyed - to draw
attention to social issues. CoCo has been arrested several times because of her protests.
[...]
Violet CoCo: ... part of what drives me is the very feeling of insecurity, of worrying about my own
and others' safety ... My focus is on the climate and ecological emergency: the most daunting
problems that confront our society, our biosphere, and our planet. We now face an existential threat.
The sixth mass extinction is underway, and threatens to extinguish 98% of life on earth. Human
behaviour is responsible for this.
The Philosophy Club: Could you tell our readers about your projects and your community?
Violet CoCo: I'm an activist in Extinction Rebellion, a global movement of mass civil resistance
to the systems of government and industry that are currently putting the habitability of our planet
at risk.
[...]
I came to the conclusion that my highest duty ... was to contribute to the greater good. This gave
me the freedom to choose to focus on working with Extinction Rebellion, rather than pursuing more
individualistic goals.
[...]
As [British natural history broadcaster] Sir David Attenborough says, 'We cannot be radical
enough' ... I'm persuaded by both moral and practical arguments that we now have an obligation to
engage in nonviolent civil disobedience. This means creating a deliberate disruption to daily life in
order to highlight hidden injustices
Violet CoCo (centre) engaging in nonviolent civil disobedience by blocking a road in
central Melbourne.
Source: Michelle Sowey, 'The philosopher activist: An interview with Violet CoCo' (2021, April 3), The Philosophy Club,
<https://thephilosophyclub.com.au/2021/04/03/philosopher-activist/>; reproduced with permission
Photographer Julian Meehan (© Julian Meehan; reproduced with permission)

Subject: Philosophy
Content:
Does the good life require taking a strong stance on moral issues? Using CoCo as your central
example, provide your own justified response to this question.

Subject: Philosophy
Content:
Compare how two thinkers studied in Unit 3 might respond to CoCo's claim that it is morally
required to engage in nonviolent civil disobedience. Justify your response.

Subject: Philosophy
Content:
Which of the two responses that you compared in part b provides the more compelling view?
Justify your response.

Subject: Philosophy
Content:
The harm which is done by credulity in a man is not confined to the fostering of a credulous
character in others, and consequent support of false beliefs. Habitual want of care about what
believe leads to habitual want of care in others about the truth of what is told to me. Men speak
the truth to one another when each reveres the truth in his own mind and in the other's mind; but
how shall my friend revere the truth in my mind when I myself am careless about it, when I believe
thing[s] because I want to believe them, and because they are comforting and pleasant? Will he
not learn to cry, "Peace," to me, when there is no peace? By such a course I shall surround myself
with a thick atmosphere of falsehood and fraud, and in that I must live. It may matter little to me,
in my cloud-castle of sweet illusions and darling lies; but it matters much to Man that I have made
my neighbours ready to deceive. The credulous man is father to the liar and the cheat; he lives in
the bosom of this his family, and it is no marvel if he should become even as they are. So closely
are our duties knit together, that whoso shall keep the whole law, and yet offend in one point, he is
guilty of all.
Source: WK Clifford, 'The Ethics of Belief', The Contemporary Review, vol. 29, Dec 1876-May 1877, p. 289

Subject: Philosophy
Content:
Based on the passage above, why does Clifford think we have a serious responsibility, both to
ourselves and to others, to form true beliefs?
End of Section

Subject: Philosophy
Content:
Compare Clifford's view about the responsibilities we have to society and ourselves when forming
beliefs with the view expressed by one other thinker studied in Unit 4.

Subject: Philosophy
Content:
Clifford believes it is dangerous to hold false beliefs, even if they are 'comforting and pleasant'.
To what extent do you agree? Justify your response.

Subject: Philosophy
Content:
Do controversial opinions cause more harm than good in society?
Discuss this question using viewpoints and arguments from two thinkers studied in Unit 4, using
case study you have studied this year as your central example.

Subject: Philosophy
Content:
'We have to be able to trust that we can believe other people and that they will believe us.'
Discuss this statement using viewpoints and arguments from two thinkers studied in Unit 4, using
case study you have studied this year as your central example.

Subject: Philosophy
Content:
'I cannot believe something I have not had the opportunity to experience directly.'
Discuss this statement using viewpoints and arguments from two thinkers studied in Unit 4, using
case study you have studied this year as your central example.

If you use any additional Question and Answer Books to complete your responses, write your student
number on the front cover. At the end of the examination, place the additional Question and Answer
Books inside the front cover of the first Question and Answer Book.
Assessment criteria
Section
Each of the four 10-mark questions in Section A will be assessed against the following criteria:
•	 understanding of philosophical concepts, arguments, viewpoints and/or perspectives, as expressed
within the extract / set texts and as relevant to the demands of the question
•	 understanding of connections, similarities and differences between arguments, viewpoints
or perspectives, as expressed within the extract / set texts and as relevant to the demands of
the question
•	 evaluation and/or critical comparison of relevant arguments, viewpoints or perspectives, and/or the
formulation of a justified philosophical position that addresses the demands of the question
•	 plausibility, coherence and development of a reasoned and supported response that addresses the
specific demands of the question
•	 use of clear and precise language appropriate to philosophy
Section
The 20-mark essay response in Section B will be assessed against the following criteria:
•	 knowledge and understanding of philosophical concepts, viewpoints, arguments and perspectives,
expressed in the set texts and relevant to the topic
•	 evaluation and critical comparison of arguments, viewpoints or perspectives as relevant, and
formulation of a justified philosophical position in response to the topic
•	 knowledge and use of a relevant case study
•	 plausibility, coherence and development of a reasoned and supported discussion that addresses the
specific demands of the topic and integrates relevant material
•	 use of clear and precise language appropriate to philosophy
